'''Thorvald Nicolai Thiele''' (24 December 1838 – 26 September 1910) was a [[Denmark|Danish]] [[astronomer]], [[actuary]] and [[mathematician]], most notable for his work in [[statistics]], [[interpolation]] and the [[N-body problem#Three-body problem|three-body problem]].  He was the first to propose a mathematical theory of [[Brownian motion]].{{citation needed|date=July 2014}}  Thiele introduced the [[cumulant]]s and (in Danish) the [[likelihood function]]. Thiele was named by [[Ronald Fisher]], in his (short) list of the greatest statisticians of all time.<ref>
* Neyman, J. [1956]: ‘Note on an Article by Sir Ronald Fisher,’ ''Journal of the Royal Statistical Society'', Series B (Methodological), 18, pp. 288–94.
</ref>

In the early 1900s he also developed and proposed a generalisation of [[approval voting]] to multiple winner elections called [[Sequential proportional approval voting]],<ref>http://journals.lub.lu.se/index.php/st/article/view/1949/1528&usg=ALkJrhiuUQ1zCqZHnca_-iAmk1KpNqMtmg</ref> which was briefly used for party lists in [[Sweden]] when proportional representation was introduced in 1909.

Thiele also was a founder and Mathematical Director of the [[Codan A/S|Hafnia Insurance Company]] and led the founding of the [[Danish Society of Actuaries]]. It was through his [[insurance]] work that he came into contact with fellow mathematician [[Jørgen Pedersen Gram]].

Thiele was the father of [[Holger Thiele]].

[[Asteroid]]s [[843 Nicolaia]] (found by his son) and [[1586 Thiele]] are named in his honour.
